case_vignette: A 39-year-old woman presents to your office with 4 days of fever, sore throat, generalized aching, arthralgias, and tender nodules on both of her shins that arose in the last 48 hours. Her medical history is negative for disease and she does not take oral contraceptives or any other medication regularly. The physical examination reveals the vital signs that include body temperature 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate 85/min, blood pressure 120/65 mm Hg, tender and enlarged submandibular lymph nodes, and an erythematous, edematous, and swollen pharynx with enlarged tonsils and a patchy white exudate on the surface. She is not pregnant. Examination of the lower limbs reveals erythematous, tender, immobile nodules on both shins. You do not identify ulcers or similar lesions on other areas of her body.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

She has not traveled or been in contact with anyone with similar symptoms. She denies any recent changes in diet, breathing difficulties, or lifestyle. The patient reports a red and swollen throat with a white coating, as well as red, tender lumps on both shins, with no history of insect bites or stings. She has joint pain and is not aware of any exposure to specific viral or bacterial infections. There has been no recent travel, environmental exposures, weight loss, or changes in diet or lifestyle. The patient has not taken any new medications or supplements and reports no changes in her menstrual cycle or reproductive health. Swallowing is difficult due to the sore throat, with no reported exposure to respiratory infections. The patient has a fever and generalized body aches, without recent contact with sick individuals and no changes in her menstrual cycle or reproductive health.
